albase:priest-allowcharselonce-desc:
The priest can grant you the right to change your class once — but not for free.

He demands a cleansing rite: track down and destroy those who defile the surroundings.

After the rite you will receive a blessing and can use .charsel once. You can only do this again after 360 in-game days.
albase:priest-allowcharselonce-reward: Priest: The blessing is granted. You can now use .charsel once. Next time — in 360 in-game days.
albase:priest-allowcharselonce-journal-t:
The priest in the temple offered a rare mercy: the right to change your class once.

But a blessing is never free.

He demands a cleansing rite:
Track down and destroy those who defile the surroundings.

The targets of the rite can vary; the priest will name new foes when you accept the task.

Complete the rite and return to receive the blessing.
albase:priest-allowcharselonce-reward-jo:
The rite is complete.

The priest granted the blessing and allowed a single change of class and appearance.

Use the .charsel command when you are ready.
This can be done only once.

You will not be able to receive this permission again for at least 360 in-game days.
albase:dialogue-priest-intro: Peace be with you. What do you seek here?
albase:dialogue-priest-changeclass: I want to change my class.
albase:dialogue-priest-aboutblessing: Tell me about the rite and the blessing.
albase:dialogue-priest-close-answer: Go in peace. When you are ready, return.
albase:no-quest-available-priest: The rite to change your class can be performed only once every 360 days.
albase:no-quest-available-priest-cooldow: The rite to change your class will be available in {0} day(s).
albase:dialogue-priest-whoareyou-answer: I have served here for many years. I do not seek power—only to keep people from despair and to remind them that order is still possible.
albase:dialogue-priest-abouttemple-answe: You stand in the Church of the White Lotus, in the parish people call “Crossroads”. Here roads and fates meet: travelers find shelter, and the lost find a chance to begin again.
albase:dialogue-priest-aboutblessing-ans: A blessing is not a coin. It has a cost: patience and deeds. The cleansing rite is simple—find those who defile the surroundings, and prove you can finish what you start.
albase:dialogue-priest-final-text: The blessing is granted. You may now change class and appearance once via .charsel. You can only receive this again after 360 in-game days.
albase:innkeeper-firstimpression-desc: The innkeeper dislikes noise and doesn't trust words. He judges people by what they do. Do a short job nearby, and he'll hand you supplies without extra talk. This job is available only once.
albase:innkeeper-firstimpression-journal: The innkeeper spoke in short, sharp sentences. He said he doesn't give work to everyone—he tests first. The job is simple: travel a bit on foot and deal with the target he assigns. No noise. Then return.
albase:innkeeper-quietpatrol-desc: At night, something's always rustling around the inn. The innkeeper hates trouble at his doorstep. Walk the area, put down what comes too close, and don't make a scene. He pays in supplies. His work rotates about once a month.
albase:innkeeper-quietpatrol-journal-tex: The innkeeper told you to make a round. At night, something's always rustling around the inn. He wants it quiet at his doorstep. Go on foot, clear what he points at, then return.
albase:innkeeper-badcustomers-desc: Some people come to an inn not for food, but for noise. The innkeeper can't stand them. Deal with what prowls nearby. He'll pay with something useful for the road. His work rotates about once a month.
albase:innkeeper-badcustomers-journal-te: The innkeeper said: “Unwanted guests get sent away quietly.” Something is prowling near the inn. Deal with it without dragging trouble to the door. Then return.
albase:innkeeper-silentdeliveries-desc: The innkeeper needs you to go farther than usual. Clear what blocks the road. Return without stories. He pays well for quiet work. His work rotates about once a month.
albase:innkeeper-silentdeliveries-journa: He gave you an errand and watched as if expecting you to argue. This is not about strength—it's about keeping your head: go farther than usual on foot, clear the problem, and return without stories.
albase:innkeeper-foxthief-desc: Something stole supplies from the inn. Small tracks, red fur. The innkeeper wants it to end quietly. Fix it and you'll get your share. His work rotates about once a month.
albase:innkeeper-foxthief-journal-text: In the morning, the innkeeper noticed something missing. “A fox. Red. Bold. Stole something edible and ran into the brush.” Find the fox and end the problem. Then return.
albase:innkeeper-cellarwatch-desc: The innkeeper keeps things in his cellar that should stay undisturbed. At night, you can hear scraping. He won't explain—he just wants the job done. Keep it quiet and he'll pay. His work rotates about once a month.
albase:innkeeper-cellarwatch-journal-tex: The innkeeper said: “If you hear creaking at night—it's not the wind.” Check around and push back whatever is drawn to the cellar. Quietly. Then return.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-firstimpressio: You'll do. Take some food and bandages. If you want more work, come back later.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-quietpatrol-fi: It's quiet at my door. I like that. Take the supplies. No stories.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-badcustomers-f: No noise. Good. The bag and twine will help. The rest is a bonus.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-silentdeliveri: You came back. Means your head is still attached. Bread and supplies. Remember: people here like silence.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-foxthief-final: There. The fox is fed—you will be too. Take it. And don't tell the whole town.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-cellarwatch-fi: The cellar should be quiet. Tonight it is. Bandages and supplies. Take them.
albase:innkeeper-firstimpression-reward-: The test is done. The innkeeper decided you can handle quiet work. If you want more, his jobs rotate about once a month.
albase:innkeeper-quietpatrol-reward-jour: The area around the inn is quieter. The innkeeper prefers it that way. He paid you without extra words.
albase:innkeeper-badcustomers-reward-jou: Fewer unwanted guests linger near the inn. The innkeeper noted you didn't make a scene. To him, that matters more than brute force.
albase:innkeeper-silentdeliveries-reward: The errand is done. He didn't ask for details—only results. Everything else is talk.
albase:innkeeper-foxthief-reward-journal: The red shadow won't steal from the inn again. The innkeeper said, “Better this way.” And, as usual, pretended he didn't care.
albase:innkeeper-cellarwatch-reward-jour: The night is quieter. The innkeeper still won't say what he guards down there, but the cellar can ‘sleep’ again. He paid you right away.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-intro: Are you here to drink or to stare?
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-whyso: Why so grim? You look like you've seen a ghost.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-close-answer: Don't slam the door. I hate that.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-whoareyou-answ: I run this inn. I see a lot of people. I don't like the noisy ones. Drunks, least of all. If you came to chatter, wrong door.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-aboutplace-ans: An inn. Roof, food, fire. And silence—if we're lucky. If you can behave, you're welcome.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-whyso-answer: Smiles are for people who don't owe anything. I don't know you yet. Don't push it—it's easier that way.
albase:no-quest-available-innkeeper: Innkeeper: No work right now. Good.
albase:innkeeper-missingmugs-desc: In the morning, some mugs are missing. No one confesses. The innkeeper wants you to handle it quietly. His work rotates about once a month.
albase:innkeeper-missingmugs-journal-tex: The innkeeper said, “Mugs don't walk away on their own.” Something is prowling around the inn at night. Deal with it—and make sure everything is in its place by morning.
albase:innkeeper-talkingbarrel-desc: Something in the cellar is knocking, as if a barrel decided to talk. The innkeeper wants silence—and no stories. His work rotates about once a month.
albase:innkeeper-talkingbarrel-journal-t: At night, you can hear it from the cellar: knocking and scraping. The innkeeper said, “This is not a joke. Make it stop.”
albase:innkeeper-doorposter-desc: Someone is leaving notes on the inn's door that make the innkeeper's eye twitch. He won't read them—he just wants it to stop. His work rotates about once a month.
albase:innkeeper-doorposter-journal-text: Another note on the door. The innkeeper said, “One more time, and I'll go out there myself.” Make sure they stop writing.
albase:innkeeper-nightrunhunt-desc: The innkeeper doesn't like torches on the doorstep at night. Too much light brings eyes and teeth. Make a quick run through the dark and put down what stalks the road. This is not a regular job. Do it at night.
albase:innkeeper-nightrunhunt-journal-te: He spoke low: “Run the roads at night. Quietly. No lantern parade.” Cover ground on foot and deal with what follows the light. Then return before dawn.
albase:innkeeper-raccoonraid-desc: Wolves have been circling near the inn at night. Guests are jumpy and animals won't settle. The innkeeper wants them gone. Keep it quick, keep it quiet.
albase:innkeeper-raccoonraid-journal-tex: Wolves are prowling too close to the inn. I need to drive them off before someone ends up as a meal.
albase:innkeeper-quietblade-title: Innkeeper: The Right Kind of Work
albase:innkeeper-quietblade-desc: Sometimes the innkeeper needs a problem solved far from the inn—quietly, with no witnesses and no stories. Go far. Remove what he points to. Come back without boasting. He rewards useful people.
albase:innkeeper-quietblade-journal-text: He didn't look up: “If you want to be useful—go. Farther than usual.” Two targets. No noise. Return when it's done.
albase:innkeeper-nightjog-desc: They say night walks are good for your health. Take a walk... far away. Very far. And don't let me see you until dawn. I'll pay for the trouble.
albase:innkeeper-nightjog-journal-text: The innkeeper sent me on a 'night jog'. I think he just got tired of me. I need to walk 10,000 meters before dawn.
albase:innkeeper-nightjog-reward-journal: The night walk is over. I'm back. The innkeeper silently handed me some food. I don't think he expected me to return.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-nightjog-final: You're back. Alive. Well, what do you know. Here, you earned it.
albase:innkeeper-nightmantle-desc:
The innkeeper watches you in silence, as if counting every job you've done. Then he nods: you've proven you can finish quiet work without stories.

One last test: no speeches — he'll name a couple of targets. How many will be up to chance.
albase:innkeeper-nightmantle-journal-tex:
He called me over without explanation. The test isn't over yet. The innkeeper handed me a list of targets — prowlers on the roads and outskirts. How many there will be is up to chance.

If I do it clean, I'll get his mark.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-nightmantle-fi:
People love talking about "heroes". Talk makes me sick. You didn't talk. You worked.

Take this pin. It's simple, but I don't hand these to strangers. Wear it—and keep a low profile. And remember: it's not decoration. It's a mark.
albase:innkeeper-nightmantle-reward-jour: The innkeeper gave me a plain silver pin. Not for looks — for work. I think I'm no longer just hired hands to him. I'm one of his.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-missingmugs-fi: The mugs are in place. Means the night was quiet. Take the supplies. And don't ask questions.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-talkingbarrel-: It's quiet now. Good. Take this. If anyone asks, you heard nothing.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-doorposter-fin: No notes. Better this way. Take the supplies. Let them write at their own homes from now on.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-nightrunhunt-f: Night roads are for those who can keep their head. You did. Take this and don't brag about it.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-raccoonraid-fi: It's quieter now. Means you did it. Take this.
albase:dialogue-innkeeper-quietblade-fin: You went far. Came back. Didn't make noise. That's the right kind of work. Take it.
albase:innkeeper-missingmugs-reward-jour: The mugs no longer ‘disappear’ on their own. The innkeeper was pleased you didn't make a scene.
albase:innkeeper-talkingbarrel-reward-jo: The cellar fell silent. The patrons were left without a show. The innkeeper said that's how it should be.
albase:innkeeper-doorposter-reward-journ: The notes on the door have stopped appearing. The innkeeper handed over the supplies and pretended it was just another day.
albase:innkeeper-nightrunhunt-reward-jou: The roads felt quieter after the run. The innkeeper approved—without changing his tone. Night work is different. He only offers it rarely.
albase:innkeeper-raccoonraid-reward-jour: The wolves stopped circling the inn. The innkeeper paid without extra words.
albase:innkeeper-quietblade-reward-journ: The errand is done. No witnesses, no stories. The innkeeper seemed satisfied. For him, that's praise.
albase:test-desc:
Debug quest for checking every VSQuest objective type.

Test area: 512000 3 512000 (do not go below y=3).

Auto-setup on accept:
- Gives 1 stick (for Have item).
- Sets player attribute vsquest:test-attr=1 (for Player attribute).
- Pre-marks interact points for interactat/interactcount.
- Rolls 1 randomkill slot.

Manual checks:
- Travel: run a bit during DAY (06:00–18:00), progress should increase.
- Block interacts: right-click blocks at 512000,3,512000 then 512000,4,512000 then 512000,5,512000.
- Interact with NPC: interact with the Innkeeper once.
- Nearby flowers: place 1 flower-* block near you.
- Reach point: get within radius 5 of 512000,3,512000.
- Kill near point: kill any mob within radius 15 of 512000,3,512000.
- Inside land claim: enter a land claim named TestClaim.
- Survive temporal storm: wait for 1 temporal storm to end.

Tip: each completed objective will print a message and play a sound.
